notifications.body: Even the best were beginners once: We asked long-time Java experts to share their experience and tips to find out what they wish they had known before beginning their Java careers. With Java having been in business for over 25 years now, let’s hear what the professionals had to say.
notifications.title: What Java experts wish they had known

notifications.body: Vaadin recently released Collaboration Engine, a new feature that allows you to easily create real-time multiuser apps. In this post, we take a look under the hood to see how it works.
notifications.title: Inside the (Collaboration) Engine Room

notifications.body: Unsafe email validation RegEx in Vaadin 7 and 14-17 allows unauthenticated attackers to cause uncontrolled resource consumption by submitting malicious email addresses.
notifications.title: Regular expression denial of service (ReDoS)

notifications.body: The words “offline” and “web application” have been mutually exclusive for a long time, but this has now changed: most browsers have added a set of APIs to enable offline use cases. With Vaadin 19, we improved our offline support to enable you to build complete offline work flows. You can create apps that start offline and let users see cached data when they open the app and navigate between views.
notifications.title: Vaadin 19 adds offline functionality to Fusion: here's how it works

notifications.body: Vaadin 19 comes with some long awaited updates, including simplified theming, OSGi compatibility for Flow and improved offline support for Fusion (TypeScript) applications. Read on to learn more.
notifications.title: Vaadin 19 has landed: Here’s everything you need to know

notifications.body: Justin Fagnani, Google software engineer, and creator of lit-html, joined us for a Vaadin webinar in which he presented the new and exciting releases of LitElement 3.0 and lit-html 2.0. You can find the full recorded webinar on Youtube or continue reading for a written summary.
notifications.title: LitElement 3.0 and lit-html 2.0 webinar with Justin Fagnani

notifications.body: Vaadin has enabled Java development teams to build full-stack applications, 100% in Java, for over 20 years. With an extensive web component library, powerful abstraction capabilities, the new Collaboration Engine (for real-time collaboration) and Vaadin Fusion (for TypeScript support), Vaadin is more capable than ever.
notifications.title: Java for front-end development in 2021

notifications.body: A couple of weeks ago I was coding a demo app when it dawned on me that if I was to use my code in a real-world application, it would consume unacceptable amounts of memory once it reached 100 or more concurrent users. Vaadin Flow makes it easy to start coding web applications, even if you have no experience with web development. The fact that it encapsulates the underlying request-response paradigm that is present in every web application, also makes it easy to forget that you are coding a web application and that there is a server sharing limited computing resources between concurrent users.
notifications.title: Top 5 most common Vaadin performance pitfalls and how to avoid them

notifications.body: Java is still going strong after 25 years! We decided to interview active Java professionals who have used it for years to hear about the new and upcoming features they are most excited about. notifications.title: What’s new in Java?
